June 18, 2006: Fiction
THE HUSBAND, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A man whose wife is kidnapped
has 60 hours to come up with a huge ransom.
BEACH ROAD, by James Patterson and Peter de Jonge. (Little, Brown, $27.95.)
An East Hampton lawyer becomes involved in a highly publicized trial that pits
locals against the super-rich.
AT RISK, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $21.95.) A Massachusetts state
investigator applies DNA and other forensic techniques to a cold murder case;
written as a serial for The New York Times Magazine.
THE BOOK OF THE DEAD, by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. (Warner,
$25.95.) The final volume of a trilogy involving Secret Agent Aloysius Pendergast
of the F.B.I. and his criminal brother.
THE COLD MOON, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The forensic
detective Lincoln Rhyme tracks a serial killer who calls himself the Watchmaker.
DEAD WATCH, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) A political operative
investigates the murder of a former senator.
DARK SIDE OF THE MOON, by Sherrilyn Kenyon. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A
reporter tries to expose a ring of vampires out to take over Seattle; a "Dark-Hunter"
novel.
KILLER DREAMS, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $26.) A researcher battles the head
of a pharmaceutical company who has perverted a technology she invented in
order to turn people into zombies.
THE HARD WAY, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $25.) When his wife is kidnapped, a
man who deals in illegal soldiers turns to the former military cop Jack Reacher.
BETRAYAL, by Aaron Allston. (Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) In the era of
Luke Skywalker's legacy, the Skywalker and Solo clans find themselves on
opposing sides; a "Star Wars"novel.
TWO LITTLE GIRLS IN BLUE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$25.95.) A small girl communicates telepathically with her kidnapped twin.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated
edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of
Leonardo and to the discovery of a secret society.
DIGGING TO AMERICA, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $24.95.) Two families, one of
them Iranian-American, become involved with each other when both adopt baby
girls from Korea.
Non-Fiction
DISPATCHES FROM THE EDGE, by Anderson Cooper. (HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The CNN correspondent describes a year of covering the tsunami in Sri Lanka, the
war in Iraq and Hurricane Katrina.
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
WISDOM OF OUR FATHERS, by Tim Russert. (Random House, $22.95.) The
host of "Meet the Press'' presents readers' letters about their fathers in responseto
his book "Big Russ and Me.''
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50;
updated and expanded edition, $30.) A columnist for The New York Times
analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy.
MAYFLOWER, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $29.95.) How America began, from
the author of "In the Heart of the Sea."
MYTHS, LIES, AND DOWNRIGHT STUPIDITY, by John Stossel. (Hyperion,
$24.95.) The "20/20" anchor questions conventional wisdom.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
MY LIFE IN & OUT OF THE ROUGH, by John Daly with Glen Waggoner.
(HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the bad-boy golf champion.
DON'T MAKE A BLACK WOMAN TAKE OFF HER EARRINGS, by Tyler Perry.
(Riverhead, $23.95.) Musings on life from the man behind "Diary of a Mad Black
Woman."
BEYOND BAND OF BROTHERS, by Dick Winters with Cole C. Kingseed.
(Berkley, $24.95.) The war memoirs of the commander of Easy Company, made
famous by Stephen Ambrose's "Band of Brothers."
BURNT TOAST, by Teri Hatcher. (Hyperion, $24.95.) The actress urges women to
pursue their own satisfaction rather than continually sacrificing for others.
MY LIFE IN FRANCE, by Julia Child with Alex Prud'homme. (Knopf, $25.95.) How
Julia Child mastered the art of French cooking: a memoir.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
